calls.tldr: Q3 2025 beat outlook with sales of $1.3B (+5%) and non-GAAP EPS of $3.88, led by retail, e-commerce, and RFID strength. Management guided Q4 sales growth of 8% to 11% with EPS of $4.20 to $4.40 and highlighted tariff mitigation progress and a $500M buyback.
bullets: Sales grew 5% to $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.6% and EPS up 11% to $3.88.
Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 11% (RFID and printing led) while EVM grew 2% on strong mobile computing and softer scanning.
Q4 guide calls for 8% to 11% sales growth and EPS of $4.20 to $4.40; full-year EPS guided to about $15.80.
calls.search_blob: Zebra Technologies ZBRA FY2025Q3 2025-10-28 Q3 2025 beat outlook with sales of $1.3B (+5%) and non-GAAP EPS of $3.88, led by retail, e-commerce, and RFID strength. Management guided Q4 sales growth of 8% to 11% with EPS of $4.20 to $4.40 and highlighted tariff mitigation progress and a $500M buyback. Sales grew 5% to $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.6% and EPS up 11% to $3.88. Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 11% (RFID and printing led) while EVM grew 2% on strong mobile computing and softer scanning. Q4 guide calls for 8% to 11% sales growth and EPS of $4.20 to $4.40; full-year EPS guided to about $15.80. Retail and e-commerce strength RFID momentum Tariff mitigation Elo acquisition Share repurchase Segment reporting change EMEA softness Frontline AI Enterprise Visibility and Mobility (EVM) Segment sales grew 2% with strong mobile computing and tougher compares in scanning. Management sees longer-term upside from AI-enabled devices and wearables. Asset Intelligence and Tracking (AIT) Segment sales grew 11% led by RFID and printing. RFID adoption continues to expand across retail, e-commerce, and logistics workflows. Regional performance North America grew 6% with strength in mobile computing and RFID; Canada was softer. Asia Pacific grew 23% led by Australia, New Zealand, India, and Japan initiatives. Latin America grew 8% on broad-based demand; EMEA declined 3% with weakness in Germany. Tariffs and pricing Expected 2025 gross profit impact reduced to about $24M after mitigation. Pricing actions expected to deliver about $60M annual benefit and roughly 1% sales growth. Capital allocation Planned $500M share repurchases over the next 12 months. Year-to-date buybacks exceeded $300M alongside Photoneo and Elo acquisitions. Demand and outlook Q3 demand was solid with some orders pulled forward; Q4 guide assumes similar year-end spend to last year. Management cited uneven demand in EMEA and Canada with manufacturing still soft. AI and refresh cycle AI opportunity seen in next-gen handhelds and wearables, driving a multi-year refresh cycle. Early pilots for AI Companion show productivity and sales conversion benefits. Why does Q4 guidance imply decelerating organic growth? Management said H2 demand matches prior expectations with some Q3 pull-forward and tougher comps. How should investors think about 2026 demand and long-term targets? Visibility is limited, but uneven demand persists while long-term growth drivers remain intact. How will the $500M buyback be deployed? Plan is to execute steadily over four quarters with flexibility to use market volatility. RFID expansion and frontline AI pilots indicate continued attach opportunities beyond core hardware. Elo integration expands the connected frontline TAM and should improve cross-sell into retail and hospitality. Pricing actions track broader industry moves in response to tariff impacts. Monitor Q4 conversion of pipeline assumed in the guide and incremental margin performance. Watch early benefits from Elo and Photoneo acquisitions on growth and EPS. Track Q4 demand in EMEA and Canada for signs of stabilization. Validate RFID growth drivers with retail and logistics channel checks. How quickly will AI Companion pilots convert into material software revenue? What is the sustainable baseline for China exposure once supply chain changes mature? Early visibility into new segment reporting (Connected Frontline and Asset Visibility and Automation). Update on tariff mitigation and pricing realization into 2026.

calls.tldr: Q3 2025 organic sales accelerated to 6% with adjusted EPS of $2.82, and orders jumped 22% to $11.9B with a book-to-bill above 1. Management raised full-year guidance again despite the Solstice spin impact, projecting sales of $40.7B-$40.9B and EPS of $10.6-$10.7, with Q4 sales of $10.1B-$10.3B and EPS of $2.52-$2.62.
bullets: Organic sales rose 6% and adjusted EPS increased 9% to $2.82; orders grew 22% to $11.9B and backlog hit another record.
Aerospace grew 12% organically (margin 26.1%); industrial automation returned to growth (+1%); building automation grew 7% with margin expansion; ESS declined 2% on licensing and catalyst timing.
Guidance raised: FY organic sales growth ~6% (5% ex-Bombardier), sales $40.7B-$40.9B, EPS $10.6-$10.7; Q4 EPS $2.52-$2.62 with segment margin 22.5% to 22.8%.
calls.search_blob: Honeywell International HON FY2025Q3 2025-10-23 Q3 2025 organic sales accelerated to 6% with adjusted EPS of $2.82, and orders jumped 22% to $11.9B with a book-to-bill above 1. Management raised full-year guidance again despite the Solstice spin impact, projecting sales of $40.7B-$40.9B and EPS of $10.6-$10.7, with Q4 sales of $10.1B-$10.3B and EPS of $2.52-$2.62. Organic sales rose 6% and adjusted EPS increased 9% to $2.82; orders grew 22% to $11.9B and backlog hit another record. Aerospace grew 12% organically (margin 26.1%); industrial automation returned to growth (+1%); building automation grew 7% with margin expansion; ESS declined 2% on licensing and catalyst timing. Guidance raised: FY organic sales growth ~6% (5% ex-Bombardier), sales $40.7B-$40.9B, EPS $10.6-$10.7; Q4 EPS $2.52-$2.62 with segment margin 22.5% to 22.8%. Another guidance raise Solstice Advanced Materials spin impact Aerospace acceleration Industrial automation stabilization Building automation momentum Energy project and catalyst timing Orders surge and record backlog Productivity offsets to margin pressure Aerospace Technologies Organic sales grew 12% with strength in commercial aftermarket and defense and space; commercial OE returned to growth. Segment margin declined 160 bps to 26.1% on cost inflation and acquisition headwinds, but improved sequentially. Industrial Automation Organic sales grew 1% led by sensing and warehouse automation strength. Segment margin declined 150 bps to 18.8% due to inflationary pressures. Building Automation Organic sales increased 7% with broad-based strength across solutions and products. Margin expanded 80 bps on volume leverage and productivity. Energy and Sustainability Solutions Organic sales declined 2% as licensing and catalyst deliveries shifted, offsetting refrigerants strength. Segment margin was flat at 24.5% with one-time items offsetting cost pressures. Solstice spin impact Spin expected to reduce 2025 sales by $0.7B, adjusted EPS by ~$0.21, and free cash flow by $0.2B. Like-for-like free cash flow expectations remain unchanged despite the spin. Orders and backlog Orders grew 22% with broad-based strength and book-to-bill above 1.0. Backlog reached a new record, supporting 2026 visibility. Industrial automation mix and orders Management noted timing variability in warehouse automation and mix headwinds driving Q4 softness. Orders were strong in Q3 but sustainability of short-cycle recovery remains unproven. Energy timing and margin pressure Lower energy prices delayed project licensing and catalyst shipments into 2026. Cost inflation and mix pressure drive a more cautious ESS margin outlook. Why does IA return to growth in Q3 but soften in Q4? Management cited order timing in warehouse automation and a tougher prior-year comparison. Is aerospace OE recovery sustainable? Management described OE revenue as recoupling to build rates with strong orders supporting H2 growth. How should investors model the Solstice spin impact? The spin reduces 2025 sales by ~$0.7B and adjusted EPS by ~$0.21, with like-for-like FCF unchanged. Record orders and book-to-bill above 1.0 imply sustained long-cycle demand into 2026. Solstice separation clarifies capital allocation and could improve margins in the remaining portfolio. Aerospace aftermarket and defense strength continues to outpace peers with slower OE recovery. Track Q4 ESS licensing and catalyst shipment timing versus the lower guide. Watch IA mix and margin trajectory as warehouse automation order timing normalizes. Check channel signals on aerospace OE inventory drawdown and delivery cadence. Validate ESS project timing and catalyst order pipelines for 2026. How quickly can pricing offsets close the inflation gap in aerospace margins? Will IA short-cycle demand hold up as comps get tougher in Q4? Q4 organic sales delivery versus 8% to 10% guidance. Solstice separation execution and any stranded cost disclosures.

calls.tldr: Q2 2025 beat outlook with ~$1.3B sales (+6%), non-GAAP EPS of $3.61, and modest margin expansion despite tariffs. Management announced the pending $1.3B Elo Touch Solutions acquisition and raised full-year sales, EBITDA margin, EPS, and free cash flow guidance.
bullets: Sales rose about 6% to $1.3B with adj. EBITDA margin of 20.6% and non-GAAP EPS of $3.61 (+14% YoY).
Full-year sales growth guidance raised to 5% to 7% and EPS to $15.25 to $15.75.
Announced $1.3B acquisition of Elo Touch Solutions, expected to be immediately accretive.
calls.search_blob: Zebra Technologies ZBRA FY2025Q2 2025-08-05 Q2 2025 beat outlook with ~$1.3B sales (+6%), non-GAAP EPS of $3.61, and modest margin expansion despite tariffs. Management announced the pending $1.3B Elo Touch Solutions acquisition and raised full-year sales, EBITDA margin, EPS, and free cash flow guidance. Sales rose about 6% to $1.3B with adj. EBITDA margin of 20.6% and non-GAAP EPS of $3.61 (+14% YoY). Full-year sales growth guidance raised to 5% to 7% and EPS to $15.25 to $15.75. Announced $1.3B acquisition of Elo Touch Solutions, expected to be immediately accretive. Elo acquisition Raised guidance Tariff relief RFID strength Capital allocation Connected frontline Regional performance North America +8% with double-digit mobile computing and RFID growth. Asia Pacific +20% led by Australia, New Zealand, and India; Latin America +11%. EMEA -1% due to tough prior-year comparisons. Product and vertical trends Mobile computing, scanning, and RFID outperformed; transportation and retail led vertical growth. Manufacturing remained softer; healthcare cycled strong compare. Elo acquisition Elo brings point-of-sale, kiosks, and touchscreen solutions to expand the connected frontline portfolio. Management expects $25M of annual EBITDA synergies by year three and immediate accretion. Tariffs and pricing Full-year gross profit impact after mitigation reduced to about $30M. Annualized impact now ~$40M, aided by lower China import rates and pricing actions. Capital allocation Repurchased $250M of stock year to date. Balance sheet supports pending $1.3B Elo acquisition. Elo strategic fit Elo adds customer-facing devices and expands TAM by about $8B. Zebra expects cross-sell opportunities and broader geographic reach. Demand and guide balance Management said demand stayed resilient but customers remain cautious on trade policy. Guide reflects backlog visibility and balanced second-half assumptions. How does Elo overlap with Zebra and what is the customer synergy? Overlap is minimal; Elo adds self-service and POS solutions with cross-sell potential. What is embedded in second-half demand guidance? Backlog and pipeline support the guide; customers are cautious but executing plans. How do tariffs and pricing flow through margins? Tariff impact improved; pricing is holding outside mobile computing where exemptions apply. Elo acquisition shifts Zebra toward broader connected-frontline workflows and customer-facing endpoints. Improved tariff outlook provides margin relief and increases full-year EPS visibility. Elo operates in a fragmented market with strong IP and long-standing customer relationships. Track Q3 margin performance vs. tariff assumptions and FX headwinds. Monitor deal close timing and early integration signals for Elo. Validate Elo cross-sell opportunities in retail, hospitality, and healthcare channels. Track RFID demand and transportation logistics momentum into Q3. How quickly will Elo synergies ramp toward the $25M target? Will pricing realization improve if tariff exemptions change? Q3 sales growth delivery vs. 2% to 6% guide. Updates on Elo closing, integration planning, and tariff mitigation progress.

calls.tldr: Q2 2025 delivered 5% organic sales growth and adjusted EPS of $2.75, beating guidance with orders up 6% and backlog at $36.6B. Management raised full-year sales and EPS guidance while factoring tariffs, completed the PPE divestiture, and highlighted portfolio moves including the Johnson Matthey Catalyst Technologies deal and a building automation tuck-in.
bullets: Organic sales grew 5% with adjusted EPS up 10% to $2.75; orders rose 6% to $10.5B and backlog reached $36.6B.
Aerospace grew 6% organically (margin 25.5%); industrial automation was flat (margin 19.2%); building automation grew 8% (margin +90 bps); ESS grew 6% led by UOP.
Guidance raised: FY organic sales growth 4% to 5% (3% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $40.8B-$41.3B; Q3 sales $10.0B-$10.3B and EPS $2.50-$2.60.
calls.search_blob: Honeywell International HON FY2025Q2 2025-07-24 Q2 2025 delivered 5% organic sales growth and adjusted EPS of $2.75, beating guidance with orders up 6% and backlog at $36.6B. Management raised full-year sales and EPS guidance while factoring tariffs, completed the PPE divestiture, and highlighted portfolio moves including the Johnson Matthey Catalyst Technologies deal and a building automation tuck-in. Organic sales grew 5% with adjusted EPS up 10% to $2.75; orders rose 6% to $10.5B and backlog reached $36.6B. Aerospace grew 6% organically (margin 25.5%); industrial automation was flat (margin 19.2%); building automation grew 8% (margin +90 bps); ESS grew 6% led by UOP. Guidance raised: FY organic sales growth 4% to 5% (3% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $40.8B-$41.3B; Q3 sales $10.0B-$10.3B and EPS $2.50-$2.60. Raised full-year guidance Tariff mitigation and pricing Portfolio transformation and spin preparation Johnson Matthey Catalyst Technologies acquisition PPE divestiture completed Building automation strength Aerospace demand resilience Industrial automation mixed trends Aerospace Technologies Organic sales rose 6% led by defense and space and commercial aftermarket strength. Segment margin declined 170 bps to 25.5% on cost inflation and CASE integration. Industrial Automation Organic sales were flat with better sensing and warehouse automation offset by softer PSS and PPE. Segment margin expanded 20 bps to 19.2% on productivity and commercial excellence. Building Automation Organic sales grew 8% across solutions and products with strong regional demand. Margin expanded 90 bps on volume leverage and access solutions accretion. Energy and Sustainability Solutions Organic sales grew 6% led by double-digit UOP growth. Margin headwinds from cost inflation and a customer settlement offset LNG benefits. Portfolio actions Agreed to acquire Johnson Matthey Catalyst Technologies (GBP 1.8B) with close expected in H1 2026. Announced Lion Tammer tuck-in for building automation and launched strategic alternatives review for PSS and WWS. Tariffs and pricing Guidance assumes tariffs announced to date with mitigation via productivity and pricing actions. Margin pressure in aero reflects tariff-driven cost inflation with pricing lag. Demand contingency and orders Management said order trends improved sequentially with strong aerospace orders. Energy projects and catalyst timing remain the primary source of uncertainty. Aerospace OE and margin outlook Commercial OE revenue softness was described as transitory with expectations for improvement in H2. Aero margins are expected to recover as pricing catches up to inflation. What is driving the more cautious second-half posture? Management cited tariff uncertainty and delayed energy project and catalyst timing despite strong H1 orders. How should investors view IA short-cycle trends? Orders held up better than feared, but management remains cautious on China-exposed short-cycle businesses. Why was free cash flow guidance unchanged after raising EPS? Inventory build in aerospace is expected to normalize later in the year, offsetting higher earnings. Catalyst Technologies acquisition expands UOP exposure to sustainable fuels and should raise long-term ESS growth. Strategic alternatives for PSS and WWS could reshape the automation portfolio and improve mix. Building automation momentum and access solutions accretion point to share gains in key verticals. Track Q3 conversion of energy backlog and catalyst shipment timing. Watch aero pricing actions versus tariff cost inflation in the second half. Validate UOP catalyst demand and sustainable fuels pipeline with channel checks. Monitor PPE exit benefits on IA margins and organic growth in the second half. Timing and regulatory milestones for the Catalyst Technologies acquisition. Outcome and timing for the PSS and WWS strategic alternatives review. Q3 organic sales delivery versus the 2% to 4% guide range. Backlog conversion in aerospace and energy projects.

calls.tldr: Q1 2025 beat guidance with 4% organic sales growth, flat segment margin at 23%, and adjusted EPS of $2.51. Management maintained full-year organic sales guidance at 2% to 5% while raising EPS outlook to $10.20 to $10.50 amid tariff uncertainty, and highlighted separation planning, the Sundyne deal, and significant buybacks.
bullets: Organic sales rose 4% with adjusted EPS up 7% to $2.51; orders were $10.6B and backlog hit a record $36.1B.
Aerospace grew 9% organically (commercial aftermarket +15%) and building automation grew 8%, while industrial automation and ESS declined 2% each.
Full-year guide: organic sales growth 2% to 5% (1% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $39.6B-$40.5B, EPS $10.20-$10.50; Q2 EPS $2.60-$2.70 on $9.8B-$10.1B sales.
calls.search_blob: Honeywell International HON FY2025Q1 2025-04-29 Q1 2025 beat guidance with 4% organic sales growth, flat segment margin at 23%, and adjusted EPS of $2.51. Management maintained full-year organic sales guidance at 2% to 5% while raising EPS outlook to $10.20 to $10.50 amid tariff uncertainty, and highlighted separation planning, the Sundyne deal, and significant buybacks. Organic sales rose 4% with adjusted EPS up 7% to $2.51; orders were $10.6B and backlog hit a record $36.1B. Aerospace grew 9% organically (commercial aftermarket +15%) and building automation grew 8%, while industrial automation and ESS declined 2% each. Full-year guide: organic sales growth 2% to 5% (1% to 4% ex-Bombardier), sales $39.6B-$40.5B, EPS $10.20-$10.50; Q2 EPS $2.60-$2.70 on $9.8B-$10.1B sales. Tariff mitigation and demand uncertainty Separation into three companies Sundyne acquisition Aerospace strength Building automation momentum Industrial automation softness Capital return PPE divestiture Aerospace Technologies Organic sales rose 9% with commercial aftermarket up 15% and defense and space delivering another double-digit quarter. Segment margin declined to 26.3% on mix and CASE integration headwinds, partially offset by productivity. Industrial Automation Organic sales declined 2% with PPE weakness and softer Europe/China, while warehouse and workflow solutions returned to growth (+5%). Segment margin fell 130 bps to 17.8% on volume deleverage and receivables write-downs. Building Automation Organic sales grew 8% with double-digit growth in building solutions and strength in fire and security products. Segment margin expanded 150 bps on volume leverage, productivity, and access solutions accretion. Energy and Sustainability Solutions Organic sales declined 2%; EOP grew 2% while advanced materials fell 4% on tough flooring comps. Segment margin expanded 230 bps on LNG acquisition benefits and productivity. Tariffs and mitigation Guide assumes current tariffs net of mitigation actions and a demand contingency of roughly 1% on organic sales. Local-for-local footprint and operating system actions are expected to offset tariff impacts. Portfolio actions and capital return Announced Sundyne acquisition; PPE exit expected in early May. Repurchased $3B of stock year to date and reaffirmed opportunistic buybacks. Tariffs and demand assumptions Management said tariff impacts are embedded in guidance with mitigation actions underway. Demand uncertainty is concentrated in short-cycle IA and some energy projects. Aerospace mix and margin OE revenue softness was attributed to mix and revenue recognition timing, not volume. Aero margins are expected to remain around the Q1 run rate for 2025. How much demand destruction is embedded in the 2025 guide? Management cited about a 1% organic sales impact with roughly $0.18 EPS headwind versus the February outlook. Why did aero OE revenue lag while volumes improved? Mix of cost-over-sale products and revenue timing drove the shortfall; volumes were up and management expects improvement later in the year. What is the timing for the planned separations? Advanced materials is targeted for late 2025/early 2026, with aerospace timing to be refined as regulatory steps progress. Local-for-local manufacturing reduces tariff exposure versus more globally exposed peers. Portfolio moves (Sundyne and PPE exit) continue to tilt Honeywell toward higher-margin, long-cycle end markets. Pricing actions and productivity offsets suggest limited near-term share pressure despite tariff volatility. Monitor aero OE revenue recoupling with build rates and CASE integration cost timing. Track IA margin improvement as PPE exits and tariff mitigation actions ramp. Validate IA demand trends in China and Europe with channel checks. Confirm building automation backlog conversion pace in North America and the Middle East. How quickly will Sundyne close and contribute to 2025 results? Will tariff mitigation fully offset the $0.18 EPS headwind assumed in guidance? Q2 margin performance versus the 22.8% to 23.2% guide range. Updates on separation timeline and stranded cost planning.

calls.tldr: Q1 2025 beat outlook with over $1.3B in sales (+12%), record gross margin, and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20. Demand stayed solid into Q2, but higher tariff costs pushed down full-year margin and EPS guidance.
bullets: Sales grew 12% to over $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 22.3% and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20 (+42% YoY).
Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 18% and EVM grew 9%; all regions posted growth led by EMEA and Latin America.
Tariff outlook worsened: full-year gross profit impact now about $70M after mitigation; Q2 guide calls for ~4% to 7% sales growth.
calls.search_blob: Zebra Technologies ZBRA FY2025Q1 2025-04-29 Q1 2025 beat outlook with over $1.3B in sales (+12%), record gross margin, and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20. Demand stayed solid into Q2, but higher tariff costs pushed down full-year margin and EPS guidance. Sales grew 12% to over $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 22.3% and non-GAAP EPS of $4.20 (+42% YoY). Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 18% and EVM grew 9%; all regions posted growth led by EMEA and Latin America. Tariff outlook worsened: full-year gross profit impact now about $70M after mitigation; Q2 guide calls for ~4% to 7% sales growth. Broad-based demand Tariff mitigation Margin expansion Capital allocation Supply chain diversification Machine vision acquisition Asset Intelligence and Tracking Segment sales grew 18% on strong printing and RFID demand. RFID adoption continued across retail, logistics, and government workflows. Enterprise Visibility and Mobility Segment sales grew 9% with broad product category strength. Service and software recurring revenue grew slightly amid prior-year install base dynamics. Regional performance North America +7%, EMEA +18%, Asia Pacific +13%, Latin America +18%. Manufacturing lagged other verticals but still grew high single digits. Tariffs Annualized gross profit impact now expected at $80M to $90M after mitigation. Full-year impact estimated at about $70M with $25M to $30M expected in Q2. Capital allocation Repurchased $125M in Q1 and $75M in April. Acquired Photoneo for $62M, adding 3D machine vision capabilities. Demand stability Management said retail strength carried into Q1 and demand remained solid into April. Customers remain positive but cautious amid trade policy uncertainty. Tariff mitigation Supply chain shifts can take 12 to 18 months depending on site readiness. Pricing actions and production moves are key levers to offset tariff impact. Is demand changing as tariffs evolve? Zebra reported stable demand and projects moving forward, but customers are cautious. How quickly can supply chain shifts mitigate tariffs? Moves typically take 12 to 18 months; CapEx is limited due to partner-led production. Why was EMEA growth higher than North America? Management cited easier prior-year comparisons in EMEA and large retail projects. Tariff uncertainty is pressuring margin outlook despite strong demand and operating leverage. Photoneo acquisition expands machine vision exposure beyond core mobility and printing. Pricing actions are a key lever but realization varies by product and contract mix. Track Q2 tariff impact and pricing realization as the April price actions ramp. Watch manufacturing recovery and machine vision momentum through 2025. Monitor customer behavior for signs of tariff-driven order pull-forward. Track timing and magnitude of additional pricing actions. How quickly can additional tariff mitigation move the full-year impact below $70M? Will service and software growth re-accelerate as the installed base rebuilds? Q2 sales growth and margin impact from tariffs. Early contributions from the Photoneo acquisition.
